metadata.title: Glycerol oligomers production by etherification using calcined eggshell as catalyst

S2468-8231(17)30121-9 10.1016/j.mcat.2017.02.030 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Scheme of catalyst preparation. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Eggshell XRD pattern A) NE B) CE. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 FTIR spectra of A) NE and B) CE. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 SEM images NE catalyst A) 497x B) 1500x; CE catalyst C) 500x D) 1500x. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms at −196°C for CE and NE. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 A) TPD-CO2 curve of CE B) TG/DTG curves of NE. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 A) Typical chromatogram for products after silylation: 2min: Pyridine, 20. 5min: Glycerol, 23.5–24min: Cyclic compounds, Diglycerols, 27min: Triglycerols. B) Diglycerol isomers: α,α-diglycerol, α,β-diglycerol and β,β-diglycerol. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Glycerol conversion (XGly), selectivities for diglycerol (Sdi), triglycerol (Stri), high oligomers and other products (Sho) and oligomers yielding (Ydi and Ytri) for tests without catalyst, with 2wt% of commercial CaO and calcined eggshell (reaction conditions: 245°C, 6h). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Effect of reaction temperature on Glycerol conversion (XGly), selectivities for diglycerol (Sdi), triglycerol (Stri), high oligomers and other products (Sho) and oligomers yielding (Ydi and Ytri) (reaction conditions: 2wt% of calcined eggshell, 24h). Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Aspects of products for reactions at 200, 220 and 245°C. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Effect of catalyst loading on Glycerol conversion (XGly), selectivities for diglycerol (Sdi), triglycerol (Stri), high oligomers and other products (Sho) and oligomers yielding (Ydi and Ytri), from 0.5 to 2wt% of calcined eggshell (reaction conditions: 220°C, 24h). Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Profiles of glycerol conversion and di- and triglycerol yieldings in the etherification reaction versus time. (Reaction conditions: 2wt% of CE, 220°C). Fig. 12 Table 1 XRF results, particle size analysis and textural properties for NE and CE. Table 2 Sample Ca (mg/L) Glycerol – CaO 13680 CE 8920 CE − Calcined Eggshell. Glycerol oligomers production by etherification using calcined eggshell as catalyst F.J.S. Barros a R. Moreno-Tost b J.A. Cecilia b A.L. Ledesma-Muñoz b L.C.C. de Oliveira a F.M.T. Luna a R.S. Vieira a ⁎ a Universidade Federal do Ceará, Departamento de Engenharia Química, Grupo de Pesquisa em Separações por Adsorção − GPSA, Campus do Pici, 709, Fortaleza, CE, 60.455-760, Brazil Universidade Federal do Ceará Departamento de Engenharia Química Grupo de Pesquisa em Separações por Adsorção − GPSA Campus do Pici, 709 Fortaleza CE 60.455-760 Brazil b Universidad de Málaga, Departamento de Química Inorgánica, Mineralogía y Cristalografía (Unidad Asociada ICP-CSIC), Facultad de Ciencias, Campus de Teatinos s/n, 29071, Málaga, Spain Universidad de Málaga Departamento de Química Inorgánica Mineralogía y Cristalografía (Unidad Asociada ICP-CSIC) Facultad de Ciencias Campus de Teatinos s/n Málaga 29071 Spain ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract The growing expansion of biodiesel industries led to an increasing formation of by-products as glycerol, which can be considered as building block molecule to high-added value products. The use of natural materials, formed by calcium carbonate, has recently become an interesting approach to the development of inexpensive and widely available basic catalysts. In this work, the use of eggshell waste as catalytic precursor was evaluated in the glycerol etherification reaction to obtain glycerol oligomers. Both raw and calcined eggshell were characterized by XRD, FTIR, N2 adsorption-desorption at −196°C, particle size analysis, SEM, CO2-TPD and TG/DTG. For comparative purposes, commercial CaO was also tested. The solids were tested as-received and calcined in the reaction. Several parameters as catalyst loading, reaction temperature, reaction time and the leaching of calcium to the reaction medium were evaluated. The optimal reaction conditions for the calcined eggshell were catalyst loading of 2wt.%, temperature of 220°C and reaction time of 24h, promoting 85% glycerol conversion and oligomers yielding of 43% (Di- and Triglycerol). The material tested shows leaching; however, taking account its low cost and good basic properties, calcined eggshell can be considered as promising catalyst for glycerol oligomerization. Keywords Glycerol Etherification Eggshell waste Diglycerol Triglycerol 1 Introduction In the context of the biodiesel market, glycerol plays a very important role, since about one kilogram of glycerin is obtained for every ten kilograms of biodiesel [1]. In Brazil, for example, glycerol production has already reached about 250 thousand tons/year. Far exceeding demand and the absorption capacity of the current markets mainly based on the consumption of glycerol for cosmetics and food products [2]. The presence of three OH groups, attached to each of the three carbon atoms of glycerol, turns it in a potential candidate for a wide variety of chemical reactions. Factors such as low price and high availability makes glycerol an attractive starting material to obtain high-added value products. This fact leads glycerol to become a major chemical platform for future biorefineries [1,3]. Traditionally, glycerol plays a role in producing various types of polymers, such as polyglycerol esters, some of which are commercially available. The esters, with great potential for use in the synthesis of polymeric materials, can be obtained by glycerol oligomers esterification with carboxylic acids. Treatment of glycerol with basic or acidic catalysts and temperatures of 200°C can lead to a mixture of diglycerol, triglycerol and higher oligomers. In general, the primary hydroxyl group is more reactive functional group to obtain dimers as main product. Together these dimers, other products can be obtained by the condensation of condensation between primary-secondary hydroxyls or secondary-secondary hydroxyls leading to a variety of products [2,4,5]. Polyglycerols with a low degree of condensation (di- and/or triglycerol) are products with high interest to be used as starting material for a range of products from emulsifiers in the food and cosmetic industries to polymeric materials. These products are attractive due to their good biodegradability, high thermal stability and transparency [2,6]. Different strategies have been explored for the selection of suitable catalysts for glycerol oligomerization, both homogenous and heterogeneous catalyst with basic or acidic properties. Richter et al. [6] have evaluated the glycerol etherification using CsHCO3 by a homogeneous process in a batch reactor at 260°C. Their studies have pointed that high selectivity of linear diglycerols was achieved at low glycerol conversion, after 8h of reaction. Ruppert et al. [7] evaluated the glycerol etherification in presence of alkaline earth metal oxides. These data were compared with a homogenous process, using Na2CO3 as catalyst. The reactions were carried out at 220°C under air flow. The best selectivity values for di- and triglycerol (>90% at 60% conversion) were obtained over CaO, SrO, and BaO catalysts. Another series of experiments, different types of CaO materials were prepared. Stabilities studies performed pointed to increasing amounts of Ca from the catalyst leached to the liquid phase with reaction time. Pouilloux et al. [8] have carried out glycerol etherification at 260°C using mesoporous silica (MCM-41 and SBA-15) impregnated with cesium species as active phase. Both materials present similar glycerol conversion (74% Cs/MCM-41 and 72% for Cs/SBA-15) and diglycerol selectivities of 81% and 79%, respectively. However, the catalyst supported on SBA-15 showed to be more stable and recyclable, maintaining the selectivity after several cycles. Ayoub et al. [9] have evaluated the performance of a zeolite Y catalyst modified with lithium. Reaction was carried out at 240°C for 8h. The activity of Li-ZeY in terms of polyglycerol yield (71%) was higher than that of homogeneous LiOH under the same catalytic conditions and similar glycerol conversions were reached. Another group of materials that has been widely studied as a catalyst for glycerol etherification is the mixed oxides derived from lamellar double hydroxides. Garcia-Sancho et al. [10] have investigated the use of MgAl mixed oxides as basic catalysts for the etherification of glycerol, also evaluating the routes of synthesis of precursors by coprecipitation and urea hydrolysis. The catalysts were active in the reactions at 220°C. The highest conversion (about 51%) was found for the catalyst prepared by coprecipitation using NaOH/Na2CO3 as precipitating agent, full selectivity to diglycerols was only reached for low conversion values. Gholami et al. [11] have carried out glycerol etherification at 250°C using mixed metal oxide catalysts Ca1.6Al0.4La0.6O3 obtaining a glycerol conversion of 96% and diglycerol yield of 52%. Pérez-Barrado et al. [12] have studied the influence of acid-base properties of calcined lamellar double hydroxides of MgAl and CaAl in the catalytic etherification of glycerol at 235°C. Less acid catalysts led to lower conversion, 24% for MgAl and 40% for CaAl, respectively, but higher selectivity to di- and triglycerol that of highly acid ones. The use of natural materials, formed by magnesium and calcium carbonate as a raw material has recently become an interesting approach to the development of inexpensive and widely available precursor to obtain basic catalysts. Among such materials, it is included eggshells wastes [13,14]. The eggshell is a rich source of carbonate based minerals, used as the basis for product development in the cosmetics industry, food supplements, bioceramics bases, fertilizers, bone and dental implants and as antitartar agent in toothpastes [15]. The high content of CaCO3 that contains the eggshell leads to this material can be used as precursor to obtain heterogeneous catalysts [16]. In this study, eggshell waste was used as catalytic precursor for the glycerol etherification in the absence of solvent. It has been evaluated the influence of catalyst loading, temperature and reaction time. Finally, catalyst stability was also investigated taking account the leaching of the calcium species estimated from ICP analyses. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalysts preparation The eggshell wastes were domestically collected. The catalyst preparation consisted on washing the material several times with warm water. Then it was dried in an oven at 100°C for 2h, and then named NE (natural eggshell). After crushing, the raw eggshell powder was calcined in muffle furnace at 900°C for 2h to decompose the organic matter and carbonate species into oxide species. This sample was named CE. A scheme of the catalyst preparation is showed in Fig. 1 . 2.2 Catalyst characterization In order to study materials composition, X-ray fluorescence (X ZSXMini II Rigaku) was used. The crystalline structure of the materials before and after the thermal process was evaluated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (D/max-b, Rigaku) and thereby assess whether there was modification of its phases after the thermal treatment. FTIR was used to monitor functional group transformation during the thermal process (IR-PRESTIGE 21 SHIMADZU FTIR). Samples were analyzed in range of 400–4000cm−1, with spectral resolution 8cm−1. The textural analyses of catalysts were performed with ASAP 2420 equipment (Micrometrics). The nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements were carried out at −196°C with a sample previously treated at 90°C for 2h with N2. Pore diameter and pore volume were determined from the adsorption branch of the isotherms by the Barrett–Joyner–Hallenda (BJH) method. The surface area was determined according to the Brunauer-Elmmett-Teller (BET) method (SBET). The particle size distribution of the materials was determined with a laser particle size analyzer (Malvern), using water as solvent. The morphology of the samples was observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM), INSPECT S50V (FEI Company). The basicity of the catalysts was studied by temperature-programmed desorption of CO2, where approximately 100mg of sample was pretreated in helium flow (60mlmin−1) at 800°C for 30min (10°Cmin−1). The reaction temperature was lowered to 100°C and pure CO2 stream (60mlmin−1) was subsequently introduced into the reactor for 30min. The reaction of CO2-TPD was conducted between 100 and 800°C helium flow (10°Cmin−1 and 30mlmin−1) and the amount of CO2 evolved was analyzed using a quadrupole mass spectrometer (Balzer 02 GSB 200) equipped with a Faraday detector (0–200U) that monitored the weight of CO2 (44U) during the experiment. Thermogravimetric analysis/differential thermal analysis (TG/DTG) was carried out on a STA 449 F3–JUPITER/NETZSCH analyzer operating under the following conditions: flow of N2 of 10mlmin−1; heating rate of 40°Cmin−1; temperature range of 40–1000°C. 2.3 Catalytic studies The glycerol reactions were carried out in batch reactor (Parr model), under nitrogen flow, using 100g of glycerol. On preliminary tests it was investigated the effects of CE presence (without or 2wt.%) and also a test with commercial CaO used directly as received. All tests were evaluated after 6h reaction time at 245°C. Then, it was studied the effect of temperature (200, 220 and 245°C, after 24h) and catalyst loading (0.5, 1, 2wt.%, 24h) with CE catalyst. Kinetic reaction was accomplished and monitored at the times of 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 and 24h. Sampling occurred through a tube inserted into the middle of the reaction medium and a valve allowed the withdrawal of aliquots during the reaction without opening the reactor. 2.4 Products characterization Product analysis was measured using gas chromatography with a flame ionization detector GC-FID (Agilent) after silylation with BSTFA [17], the adapted methodology consisted on dissolving an aliquot of 60mg of the reaction mixture in dry pyridine (Sigma-Aldrich), then 150μl of this dissolution is added to 150μl of the silanizing agent, then it was then dissolved in pyridine. The solution was aged in an oven at 60°C for one hour. It was used a CP-Sil 5CB column (100% dimethylpolysiloxane, 25m×0.25mm×0.25μm). The chromatograph oven was programmed as follow: heating ramp of 1°Cmin−1 from 80°C to 100°C and then the temperature was raised up to 300°C with a heating rate of 25°Cmin−1, finally the temperature was maintained during 5min; injector temperature of 250°C and detector temperature of 280°C. The detected compounds were unreacted glycerol, di- and tri-glycerol. Glycerol conversion (X Gly ) was calculated using the following Equation: (1) X G l y = n 0 − n f n 0 100 where, n 0 is the initial amount of glycerol mol and nf is the final amount of glycerol mol. The Selectivity (S olig ) was calculated using Eq. (2). C ( em % molar ) = n 0 − n f n 0 d (2) S o l i g = n o l i g n 0 − n f 100 where nolig is the amount of each oligomer in mol. Yieldings were calculated using Eq. (3). (3) Y o l i g = X G l y ∑ S o l i g 100 Oligoglycerols higher than triglycerol were not be detected by this analytical procedure, so that other products no detected were labeled as “others” which could include acrolein among others. The determination of Ca leaching in the reaction medium was carried out by ICP using an ICP-OES Thermo Fisher Scientific (Model iCAP 6000) equipment. A calibration curve was prepared by using an aqueous multielemental standard solution of Ca and Mg. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts XRF analysis (Table 1 ) showed that eggshell material both as received and calcined are mainly composed by calcium and small amounts of Sr, K and P. Thermal processes did not cause significant change in the elemental composition of the materials. Eggshell XRD pattern of both as received and calcined forms are shown in Fig. 2 . For NE (Fig. 2A) main peak appeared at 2θ=29.51°. In addition, this diffraction pattern shows several peaks at 2θ=23.36°,31.52 36.17°, 39.57°, 43.30°, 47.51°, 48.86°, 56.84°, 57. 71°, 60.88° and 65.06°, related to the presence of CaCO3 (ICSD N: 00-005-0586). After the thermal process (900°C for 2h), it was observed that the CE XRD pattern (Fig. 2B) showed more defined peaks, located at 32.2°, 37.3°, 58.9°, 64.2°, 67.3° which are related to the existence of CaO phase (ICSD N: 00-037-1497). According to Khemthong et al. [18], the modification of the intensity peaks is an evidence that the calcined sample displays higher crystallinity after the heat treatment process. The transmittance FTIR spectra of both NE and CE are shown in Fig. 3 . NE (Fig. 3A) showed bands located at around 1418cm−1, 870cm−1 and 743cm−1 are associated to the presence of the out-of-plane bending, the asymmetric stretching and the in-plane bending modes of the carbonate groups [19]. Besides the vibration modes, the combination of previous bending modes such as at 1800cm−1, at 2510cm−1 and 2840cm−1 have also been detected [20] this fact is in agreement with the XRD results and with those results reported by Tsai et al. [21]. Finally, the band with a maximum located at 3440cm−1 has been attributed to H-bonded water of the humidity of the calcite while band located at 1640cm−1 is attributed to the bending vibration of the water [22]. CE FTIR spectra (Fig. 3B) presents narrow bands at around 3640cm−1 and 3430cm−1, which are ascribed to the stretching (OH) of Ca(OH)2 and H2O, respectively, indicating that the surface was hydroxylated and the adsorption of water on the CaO surface [19]. Band at 1627cm−1 is ascribed to the bend mode of water, and the bands appearing around 1440cm−1 and 920cm−1 are associated with stretching CO3 −2 due to CO2 chemisorption on the surface of the material. Thus, the surface of CE is partially carbonated, probably due to the handling of the samples during the analysis. The wide and strong band at around 500cm−1 corresponds to the CaO band, in agreement with reported results [14,23–25]. From SEM micrographs (Fig. 4 ), it can be observed that the natural eggshell (Fig. 4A,B showed irregular surface and heterogeneous particle size distribution. After calcination (Fig. 4C,D), the structure of the eggshell has been changed to a more homogenous particle size distribution and smaller particle size, which can be attributed to decarbonation step to obtain CaO is an exothermic process. The data related to particle size analysis of natural and calcined materials is also presented in Table 1. After thermal treatment, the eggshell increased fines amount (D10%) from 176.21 to 228.71μm and pronounced reduction of D50% (from 534.24 to 426.61μm) and D90% (1068.12–751.08μm.). The average particle diameter was reduced by approximately 21%. According to Sanosh et al. [26] particles with size exceeding 1000μm can be attributed to aggregation of particles during calcination. Fig. 5 and Table 1 shows N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and textural parameters for natural and calcined eggshells. Both materials are Type II solids (based on IUPAC classification), typical non-porous solids characterized by low slope in the middle region of the isotherm and a desorption line almost overlapping the adsorption line, hence without a noticeable hysteresis loop. For calcined material, it is observed a significant increase in the volume of nitrogen adsorbed, which is attributed to the formation of higher amount interparticle voids instead of a porous network, improving the pore volume of the catalyst [14,21,25,27]. CO2-TPD analysis was performed in order to obtain information about basicity of eggshell after calcination (Fig. 6 A). The Figure shows the presence of two basic sites with different strengths. The low intensity peak between 100 and 200°C with maximum desorption near at 140°C indicates the presence of low basic strength sites, probably due to physisorbed CO2. The peak located between 400 and 700°C with maximum at about 625°C indicates the presence of strong basic sites on the CaO surface. This result is similar to that obtained by Lopez-Granados et al. [25] and Lee et al. [28], measuring CO2 desorption on commercial CaO. The major contribution to the total basic sites is due to the desorption of CO2 that takes place at high temperatures [13]. The presence of that compound is in accordance with XRD, XRF and FTIR results. The result of thermal analysis (TG/DTG) of eggshell in the natural form is presented on Fig. 6B. It is possible to notice that eggshell has a first mass loss of 4.47% between 40 and 700°C, attributed to the loss of water and organic matter. A second event, around 700–875°C (peak at 830°C) has 44.97% of mass loss, which according Khemthong et al. [18] is assigned to the evolved CO2 and therefore the formation of CaO takes place at that temperature. 3.2 Catalytic results Fig. 7 a shows a typical chromatogram obtained after silylation of glycerol etherification products, taking into account the chromatograms of standard reference compounds to establish retention times. Diglycerol peaks are the most intense, comprising linear isomers α, α-diglycerol, α, β-diglycerol and β, β-diglycerol (Fig. 7b). There is a shift of the distribution of diglycerol isomers, based on reaction probabilities previously reported by other authors, α, α-diglycerol will be formed more readily. The highest peak can be assigned to the α, α-diglycerol, which has smaller size (0.681nm) compared to the branched isomers (0.734nm for α,β- and 0.686nm for the β,β-dyglycerol)[6,17,29]. Due to the pore diameter of CE (7.5nm), diglycerol oligomers size has no influence on the isomers distribution for this case. The increase on viscosity due to the heating and oligomers mixture formation is also playing an important role on the selectivity. The isomer α,α-diglycerol is preferentially involved in further oligomerization. At longer reaction time, the dimer distribution is modified, specifically at higher catalyst concentration, and the percentage of α,α-diglycerol decreases, with the corresponding increase of α,β-diglycerol and β, β-diglycerol yields [6]. The chromatogram shows triglycerol isomers at 27min, with lower intensity than those linear isomers. 3.2.1 Blank test First, the contribution of the thermal reaction was evaluated (see Fig. 8 ) by putting glycerol in the reactor in absence of catalyst. Such contribution was measured at 245°C and after 6h of reaction. The glycerol conversion was of 24% and the selectivity was directed to the formation of diglycerol (selectivity of 28%). Moreover, the catalytic performance of CE catalyst was compared with commercial CaO (VETEC). It observed that calcined eggshell increases glycerol conversion from 24% at the thermal reaction and 21% from commercial CaO to 80%. Calcined eggshell also exhibited higher diglycerol selectivity (40%) and oligomers yielding (32% for diglycerol and 2.5% for triglycerol) than thermal and commercial CaO reactions. Commercial CaO was not activated at 800°C prior the catalytic test, reaction was performed with as received material, commercial CaO had lower activity because must have been carbonated (CaCO3) having a lower activity than CaO on activated form as CE. 3.2.2 Reaction temperature Once proved the promoting effect of calcined eggshell on glycerol oligomerization, for a better understanding of its catalytic properties, it was investigated the temperature reaction effect by fixing the catalyst loading at 2wt% and after 24h of reaction time. The temperatures studied were 200, 220 and 245°C (Fig. 9 ), respectively. The results indicated that at low temperatures (200°C) the reaction does not take place in a large extension, with very low conversion and oligomers yielding (3% for diglycerol and about 1% for triglycerol). Experiments at 220 and 245°C show higher glycerol conversion as well as di and triglycerol yieldings (43 and 50%, respectively). At 245°C there is also a decrease on diglycerol selectivity compared with that at 200°C, due to the higher reaction times, which also promotes diglycerol oligomerization, in accordance with the data reported by other authors [11]. As can be seen on Fig. 10 , the product obtained at 200°C is very clear, in accordance with its composition mainly based on unreacted glycerol, the one at 245°C was dark and very viscous, indicating the occurrence of side reactions with the formation of higher oligomers and by-products [30,31]. 3.2.3 Catalyst loading Since temperature reaction of 245°C exhibited the formation of undesired products and a slightly lower oligomers yielding, catalyst loading was evaluated at 220°C, ranged from 0.5 to 2wt% of CE and 24h of reaction (Fig. 11 ). It is observed that there is a continued increase in the conversion, somewhat decrease on diglycerol selectivity, and higher triglycerol yield, achieving oligomers yieldings of 34% for diglycerol and 9% for triglycerol at 220°C. It is important to point that with 0.5wt% of catalyst loading it was possible to achieve high glycerol conversion and selectivity to oligomers (di- and triglycerol), with a temperature reaction of 220°C which is a lower temperature compared with previously reported results. Thus, these results are quite good comparing with those recently published. Pérez-Barrado et al. [11] showed a highest conversion of 75% using hydrocalcite (CaAl) calcined at 450°C, with oligomers (diglycerol and triglycerol) selectivity of 42%. Ayoub et al. [9] evaluated the performance of a lithium modified zeolite Y catalyst in the conversion of glycerol to polyglycerols in the absence of solvent. A conversion of 99% was achieved at 240°C, after 8h of reaction, with a diglycerol and triglycerol selectivity of 21% and 31%, respectively. Moreno-Tost et al. [17], investigated the use of MgFe mixed oxides, derived from layered double hydroxides (LDH). The catalyst was employed on glycerol etherification at 220°C, in a batch reactor. The highest conversion (41%) was found for the MgFeO4 catalyst prepared with Mg/Fe molar ratio of 4, with an oligomers yielding of approximately 50%. 3.2.4 Effect of reaction time Fig. 12 shows the kinetic reaction profile, for the optimized reaction conditions: reaction temperature of 220°C, 2wt% of catalyst, 100g of glycerol and 24h of reaction time. It is showed that there is a continuous increase in conversion with increasing reaction time, reaching 15% at 6h reaction. Under these conditions the conversion is significantly lower that obtained at 245°C (100% of glycerol conversion). However, as it was discussed above, at higher temperatures a higher polymerization occurs, with a consequent reduction in the amount of di- and triglycerol yield. In addition, an increase of undesired compounds production. It is observed that the kinetic is quite slow at this temperature (220°C), since it was required 24h of reaction to obtain full conversion. Diglycerol production was continuously increasing with glycerol conversion while triglycerol production started just at 6h of reaction. 3.2.5 Stability of catalysts The leaching of calcium (Table 2 ) was measured in order to evaluate the stability and reusability of the catalyst. Thus, the amount of lixiviated calcium was quantified after reaction both in the case of using CE or CaO as catalysts. It is clear that calcium from the calcined eggshell leached to the reaction medium, implying such conditions that the system is partially homogeneous. Catalyst dissolution to the liquid phase is a problem reported by several authors and it is mainly due to the high temperatures employed and strong basic conditions. Pouilloux et al. [8] quantified the leaching by ICP analysis, obtaining losses of Cs to the reaction medium from 23% for the catalyst supported on SBA-15 and 74% when Cs was supported on MCM-41. Ruppert et al. [7], using CaO from various sources (synthesized from Ca(NO3)2·4H2O, commercial CaO and synthesized from Ca(OH)2), observed that about 3–6wt% of the original calcium catalyst could be found in the liquid phase in two hours of reaction and these amounts gradually increased with reaction time. The authors concluded that the catalytic activation of different materials goes hand in hand, increasing amount of CaO in the reaction mixture. On some previous works Ca leaching is ascribed to the formation of calcium glyceroxide or also Ca(OH)2 colloids. Ruppert et al. [7] working with glycerol etherification at 220°C (same temperature used here), observed that besides the CaO solid, the active species involved might be Ca ions, in the form of calcium diglyceroxide, and also Ca(OH)2 colloids since calcium oxide particles are partially hydroxylated due to the formation of water produced on the glycerol etherification. ICP measures and cryo-TEM micrographs supported the idea that the material can defragment and form colloidal particles during the course of the reaction and their amount gradually increases with increasing reaction time. Kouyu et al. [32] employing CaO (obtained from lime stone calcination) as catalyst at the transesterification of soybean oil with refluxing methanol, observed that calcium oxide seemed to be directly turned into calcium glyceroxide. To verify this hypothesis, the collected catalyst was also employed at the reaction and it was rather active in the transesterification. Using reference sample of calcium glyceroxide as catalyst, the authors observed that it was as active as the collected catalyst. Therefore, it was clear that calcium glyceroxide, Ca[O(OH)2C3H5]2, was the active phase of the collected catalyst, due to the direct combination of calcium oxide with glycerol by-produced from soybean oil. 4 Conclusions The characterization of calcined eggshell material pointed out that the material is composed mainly of CaO. The porosity and an increased number of thin particles at the calcined material were confirmed by morphological, granulometric and textural analysis. CO2-TPD analysis indicated that the material presented two basic types of sites favoring glycerol oligomerization. Based in the experimental study, the best reaction conditions for the calcined eggshell were: catalyst loading of 2wt%, temperature of 220°C and reaction time of 24h, with 85% glycerol conversion and oligomers yielding of 43% (Di- and Triglycerol). The catalytic study also indicated that the long time reaction does not satisfactorily proceeds at 200°C, and higher temperatures (245°C) leads to higher polymer chains and undesired acrolein. The stability tests showed that the catalysts suffer from leaching into the reaction medium, an issue also reported with the use of commercial catalysts. The use of eggshell wastes as catalyst precursor is a promising option for glycerol oligomers production, since the CE material is obtained from the transformation of an abundant waste (eggshells) on a highly active catalyst through a simple and non-expensive process, leading to a material with good base catalyst properties. Besides, with this route there would be the usage of two byproducts, eggshells and glycerol, on the production of value added compounds. coredata.dc:description: The growing expansion of biodiesel industries led to an increasing formation of by-products as glycerol, which can be considered as building block molecule to high-added value products. The use of natural materials, formed by calcium carbonate, has recently become an interesting approach to the development of inexpensive and widely available basic catalysts. In this work, the use of eggshell waste as catalytic precursor was evaluated in the glycerol etherification reaction to obtain glycerol oligomers. Both raw and calcined eggshell were characterized by XRD, FTIR, N2 adsorption-desorption at −196°C, particle size analysis, SEM, CO2-TPD and TG/DTG. For comparative purposes, commercial CaO was also tested. The solids were tested as-received and calcined in the reaction. Several parameters as catalyst loading, reaction temperature, reaction time and the leaching of calcium to the reaction medium were evaluated. The optimal reaction conditions for the calcined eggshell were catalyst loading of 2wt.%, temperature of 220°C and reaction time of 24h, promoting 85% glycerol conversion and oligomers yielding of 43% (Di- and Triglycerol). The material tested shows leaching; however, taking account its low cost and good basic properties, calcined eggshell can be considered as promising catalyst for glycerol oligomerization.
coredata.dc:title: Glycerol oligomers production by etherification using calcined eggshell as catalyst
